document.docAuthor: Decae, Arthur, Pantini, Paolo & Isaia, Marco
document.docTitle: Nemesia pedemontana Decae, Pantini & Isaia, 2015, n. sp.
document.masterDocTitle: A new species-complex within the trapdoor spider genus Nemesia Audouin 1826 distributed in northern and central Italy, with descriptions of three new species (Araneae, Mygalomorphae, Nemesiidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new species-complex within the trapdoor spider genus Nemesia Audouin 1826 distributed in northern and central Italy, with descriptions of three new species (Araneae, Mygalomorphae, Nemesiidae)

Diagnosis (
Fig. 7
).
Males differ from those of other species in the
N. apenninica
group by the long, slender lightly sigmoid curved embolus (
Fig. 7
A), its dorsally regular curve (
Fig. 7
B), its gradually narrowing tip and the sharp origin of the embolus, best seen in prolateral view (
Fig. 7
D). Spermathecae composed of two slender, proximally diverging, centrally twisted receptacles. Proximal part widest. Distal part distinctly bipartite with proximal tube and distally lightly inflated dead end (
Fig. 7
E).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 7.
Nemesia pedemontana
n. sp.
, camera lucida drawings (as in Fig. 5) of right male palpal organ (A–D) and female spermathecae (E). Distribution of glandular tissue as in N. apenninica .

subSubSection.paragraph:
Description . Male holotype . Measurements: BL= 11.8 , CL= 4.3 , CW= 3.4 , Ca= 2.5 , Pa= 5.3 , L 1 = 11.7 , L 2 = 10.3 , L 3 = 9.3 , L 4 = 13.7 . Similar to
N. appenninica
except as noted. Carapace : slightly more elongate (CL/CW= 1.3 , CL/ Ca= 1.7 ), color more pronounced than in
N. hastensis
, and darker, with strongly contrasting dark and lighter zones, dark parts distinctly mottled, CZ wedge shaped, warm brown, wide and truncated behind eyes and gradually narrowing towards fovea (
Fig. 4
F), thoracic part with distinct central grey leaf-pattern with peripheral yellow zones, fovea somewhat irregular shaped, central groove small, clypeus, darker than in previous two species, bristles less developed than in previous two species, absent along carapace edges, pubescence fine silver grey. Eyes : compactly grouped on and around a steep, anteriorly light colored, process (l/w= 1.3 ), lateral eyes larger than median eyes, ALE largest (ALE/PLE= 1.2 ), AER slightly shorter than PER (AER/PER= 0.96 ), light patch between ALE, POP not uniform black. Chelicerae : dorsal dark greenish black with lighter colored glabrous zones, distribution of bristles and structure of rastellum as in previous two species. Maxillae : (l/w= 1.8 ), ventrally grayish brown further as
N. hastensis
. Labium : (l/w= 0.6 ), darker than maxillae contrasting with other ventral parts, further as in previous two species. Sternum : (l/w= 1.3 ) bright yellow with distinct dark edge, sigilla less visible than in
N. hastensis . Legs
: color pattern distinct from previous two species with dorsally dark colored femora and more conspicuous glabrous, longitudinal zones on patellae, segments laterally and ventrally much lighter with glabrous longitudinal zones on femora, spine patterns, pubescence, scopulae, claspers and claws as in
N. hastensis . Palps
: color and bristle pattern as legs, tibia (l/w= 1.9 ) slightly curved upward and less inflated than in
N. hastensis
. Palporgan : see
Fig. 7
A, D. Abdomen : distinctly darker and more intensely colored ventrally gray otherwise similar previous two species. Spinnerets : darker and more intensely colored than in
N. hastensis ,
otherwise similar.

Female paratype . Measurements: BL= 17.5 , CL= 5.8 , CW= 4.3 , Ca 3.5 , Pa= 8.5 , L 1 = 12.8 , L 2 = 11.5 , L 3 = 10.7 , L 4 = 17.1 . Similar to
N. appenninica
except as noted. Carapace : shape as in
N. hastensis
(CL/CW= 1.3 , CL/Ca= 1.6 ), color generally darker than in females of previous two species (
Fig. 4
E) with dark parts more distinctly mottled than in
N. hastensis
, CZ caudally more sharply tapering than in both previously described species, fovea, bristles and pubescence as in previous two species. Eyes : as in
N. hastensis
(l/w= 1.2 ), laterals larger than medians, POP connecting all eyes, ALE largest (ALE/PLE= 1.3 ), AER slightly longer than PER (AER/PER= 1.02 ). Maxillae : (l/ w=1, 9). Labium : (l/w= 0.5 ). Sternum : (l/w= 1.3 ). Abdomen : with large dorsal central light colored patch. Spinnerets : similar in color to ventral abdomen. Spermathecae (
Fig. 7
E): general three-partite composition and distribution of glandular tissue.
Etymology. The species name is derived from the Latin adjective pedemontanum (at the foot of the mountains), from which the region of Piemonte takes its name, and where the type series was collected.
